newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot resids steady to up, LSFO mostly gains.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot resids steady to up, LSFO mostly gains.

text.p: U.S. spot fuel oil prices were unchanged to higher again Thursday in sluggish trade, with low sulphur grades better supported by some buying interest for Florida utilities, industry sources said.

"Low sulphur doesn't look that bad. It's not a screaming buy, but it looks constructive. High sulphur feels toppy with Europe weak," said one cash trader, noting some recent buying interest into Florida.
New York Harbor physical one percent gained a quarter to $16.50-75 a barrel, with June one percent paper quoted at $17.00-25 and done at $17.25, up 25-50 cents, traders said.
NYH 0.3 percent high pour notionally edged up slightly to $17 or higher in sympathy with one percent but traders noted little underlying HP utility demand.
High sulphurs in New York again held steady, with 2.2 percent still talked at about $15 a barrel, but soft prices in Europe raised expectations for lower values soon.
U.S. Gulf one percent firmed slightly to $15.75-16.00, with 60,000 barrels for June 9 delivery reportedly sold at $17.70 (delivered Florida). The deal was not confirmed.
USG three percent notionally held at $14.75-15.00, but some thought the price was closer to $14.50, citing June three percent paper deals at $14.25 and $14.30.

New York city gate swing gas prices held relatively steady Thursday at about $2.45/mmBtu, or $15.44 a barrel equivalent. Gas at Henry Hub, the NYMEX delivery point, also was little changed at about $2.21/mmBtu, or $13.92 a barrel.
